newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Rains heading for key Brazil soybean area-forecast.
newsitem.headline: Rains heading for key Brazil soybean area-forecast.

text.p: Rains were heading for Brazil's key soybean growing region of Rio Grande do Sul overnight and could alleviate the dryness which has affected some spots, a weather forecaster said.
The National Institute of Meteorology (INMET) said the region should become cloudy today and would see generalised rains of 15 to 20 mm between Jan 30 and Feb 1.

"Tonight there is rain forecast for the whole of Rio Grande do Sul," said weather forecaster Yvanete Ledo. "It is set to rain the whole day on Jan 30 and it will continue on Jan 31 and Feb 1, mainly in the north and east."
Growers said rains had been patchy in the last 10 days but most thought it was too early to talk of crop losses.

"Currently we don't consider ourselves to be in a situation of drought," said Paulo Renato Mafsini at the Cotriba cooperative in Ibiruba. "We had 60 to 65 mm of rain about two weeks ago which really favoured the development of the soybean crop," he said. "Since then it hasn't rained and temperatures have been high."
"Conditions are relatively normal. Another one or two weeks like this would not be a problem," he said.
But a technician at the Cotrijal cooperatibve in Nao-Me-Toque said that even though dryness was localised, productivity was set to drop in some areas.
"We see a drop in productivity to 35 bags per hectare from 42 bags per hectare last year," he said.
